Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Perceptual Science and Technology

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This REU site brings eight undergraduate students to Rutgers each
summer for a ten-week research internship in the area of perceptual
science and technology. This research area centers on the challenges
and opportunities of building novel computational models that systems
may use to understand their environment and act intelligently in it.
The area affords a range of research methods, including designing
algorithms, building systems, gathering and analyzing data, and
understanding intelligence in its human context. Research projects
cover topics such as: computational approaches to the perception and
recognition of objects, faces, scenes, depth and motion; perceptual
categorization and perceptual decisions; data mining and statistical
analysis of perceptual input; search, attention, and visuo-motor
learning; visual experiences in human-computer interaction; and
computational depiction and design. The site strives to recruit and
support interns from underrepresented populations and to foster
collaborative research. Accepted students work closely with a faculty
mentor from drafting a project plan through carrying out and
presenting their research. Each project includes a pathway for two or
more interns to bring different results, data, or methods to bear on a
shared problem. The site holds workshops on research practice,
research ethics, skills for collaboration, and careers in perceptual
science and technology. Social events reinforce the sense of
community. The integrative, collaborative focus of the site offers
interns a deeper sense of range of the different careers, topics and
work environments available to them, and allows them to fine-tune a
match between their research plans and their personal goals,
backgrounds, and interests.

The site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program

POR.DRECONTENT:
From Summer 2011 through Summer 2014, this award brought 25 undergraduates to Rutgers for research internships in laboratories in Computer Science, Cognitive Science and Psychology.  They joined Rutgers students in these labs, funded by a range of related programs (including invidual NSF grants and Rutgers's own Aresty Summer Science Program).  Over the course of each summer, interns designed and carried out individual research projects under the mentorship of Rutgers faculty, postdoctoral researchers and graduate students.  They also participated in a course of workshops and discussion sessions that covered research methods, explained the process of publication and the course of research careers, introduced ethical issues in research, and allowed students to network with other scientists and research interns.  Students' research projects led to new insights into human visual perception, language processing, motor control, memory and attention; successes included helping to characterize how the visual system searches across scenes and integrates information across eye movements, modeling the relationship between how individuals move and how they perceive others' motion, and documenting how speakers produce and understand emphasis in spoken English.  Students' research projects also led to prototype systems in computer graphics, computer vision and human-computer interaction that leverage new models of human behavior and cognition; successes included inferring segmentation of 3D shape, creating linguistic descriptions of complex objects, tracking people's faces and posture using novel sensors, designing tools for building 3D models and building mobile apps to help people monitor their health.  This is the intellectual merit of the project.  Students' research experiences offered many a springboard to graduate school and further research work, while the summer activities, including both the workshop programs for undergraduates and mentoring training for Rutgers PhD students, deepened the expertise of the Rutgers community in drawing students effectively into research.  This is the broader impact of the project.
